page.lettertext:
fol.284r
Belgia 1592 29 Au
g
To my L. Trea
s
by
M
r
Hans
May it please your good L. I signified in my last
e 19 and
e 20 of
this moneth, of
e receate of suche l
re
s, as I had lately then before from
her
M
tie
and your L. of w
ch
e last
at I receaved was of
e 2 of this
p
nt
. To her M
ts
demande to have
e c
o
panies dimissed I could get
no p
nt
answear,
e
States
re
q
ring first to know
e opinions of
e
Councel
and of
e Deputies at
e Campe: w
ch
undoubtedly they did to winne a
litle time. For sins
e day
at their l
re
s were delivered at
e Campe,
they have had sufficient time to returne their advise: though
e States
doe still
p
tend
at they have not yet receaved it. But whensoever
they shall receave it, I doe not thinke
at directly they will graunt
us free libertie, although
haps they may
mite us to drawe
e
c
o
panies awaye. Whereup
o
, as in my last, I declared unto your L.
S
r
Francis Vere
and my self have bin alwais resolved,
at whensoever we
shall receave her M
ts
last l
re
for embarking
e c
o
panies, we will
make no m
a
ner of stay for w
at
of their good liking. Howbeit it
may please your L. at this p
nt
to understand to w
at
termes their
affaires are reduced. Those troupes of
e Enemy are passed
e Rine, of w
ch
I writte unto you before,
e 19 of this moneth, w
t
a
resolut int
e
t, as
e occur
e
ces give it out, and as
e apparances are
great, to beat our army fr
o
e siege, to w
ch
they are approched, as
we have certaine intellig
e
ce, w
ti
n lesse then a league.
Count
Maurice
on
e other side hath brought
e Castel of
Coevoerd
e
to
such evid
e
t distresse,
at two of our c
o
panies are lodged already w
t
in
e rampiers, and are in safetie fr
o
their shotte, for w
ch
his hope is very
great, to obtene his purpose out of hande: and is b
e
t thereup
o
, being
thorowly well entrenched, to attend
e c
o
ming of
e Enemy. Their
state standing thus, it c
a
not be
mitted w
t
out immin
e
t danger,
at
e
Englishe troupes, w
ch
are there w
t
S
r
Francis, or
e Companies of
e Co
u
trie
w
ch
should be sent by
e States, to supply
e garrison of
Berghen
, c
a
be
licensed fr
o
thence. But
e time can be but short, in all kinde of
liklyhood,
at things c
a
thus c
o
tinue. For heere we are
suaded
at ether Coevoerd
e
is taken already by
e Co
u
t, or
e Co
u
t is forced
by
e Enemy to abandon
e siege. But howsoever it be, if
e issue be
not good, I doe finde by those speeches w
ch
are c
o
monly delivered,
at
e fault will be cast up
o
her M
ts
forces, of w
ch
they saye they hav
e
fol.284v
Au
g
29
[1592]
by M
r
Hans M
r
Ma[ster]
had no use, nor her M
tie
nether, for
e time of this siege. It
is wholy against
e minde of
e States in this place, to come to a battel
w
t
e Enemy, although
e Count should be offered some notable
adv
a
tage. For they thinke
e losse of many thousandes but a
litle losse unto
e Enemy and yet to us it may turne to an ir r eparable
d
o
mage. And so they have declared by their earnest l
re
s in that
behalf. Of
e Enemies forces
Count Charles Mansfield
,
Mandragon
,
Verdugo
and one
Gonzaga
a Coronel of Spaniardes, are
chiefe c
o
ductours, having, as some men write, 7000 foot m
e
, but as
advertism
e
t
agree, 5000 at
e lest, w
ch
are pikes for
e most and
musquettiers. The nomber of their horsem
e
is not deemed muche
inferior to those
at are w
t
us, but not thought to be so good, and farre
out of order. The strenght of our forces, by all estimation is
between 7
a
d 8000 foot, and 1600 horse. The abund
a
ce of raine
w
ch
hath lately fallen heere and c
o
tinueth at this p
nt
, is a mervelouse
a
noy
a
ce to
e souldiers at
e siege, for
at
e soile of those quarters is
very fenny and moorishe. To day we doe expect to have some
l
re
s from
e Campe, and to heare of some attempt of
e Enemy up
o
us:
e sooner in
at respect,
at he is sc
a
ted of vituals, and yet is c
o
ming
hourely onward. Whatsoever shall happ
e
, shall be p
nt
ly signified
to your L.
And so I take my humble leave. Fr
o
e Hage
Au
g
29 1592.
